Comment 4: 
This is working as intended from my perspective, it's just a bit different from the way
mercurial does things.

In git, when you check out a tag, you are not on a branch.  You can start a new branch
from that point if you wish, but that's not what happens when you check out a tag.  It's
showing you the state of the files at a particular point in time, and anyone checking
out that tag at any point in history should wind up with the same files (git tags are
not supposed to move).

In git, branches are primarily used for development, and they are essentially a local
entity.  You can push them and pull them, but this only pushes and pulls the branch's
head as a special sort of tag.  When you check out a remote branch, you are also not
actually on a branch, though the operation can optionally create a local tracking branch
with the same name.
